Consumer behavior is complex and influenced by various factors such as income, social values, and personal preferences. However, there is evidence to suggest that consumers are becoming more aware and interested in sustainable and responsible manufacturing practices, which could influence their purchasing decisions.

Recent studies have shown that consumers are increasingly willing to pay more for sustainable products, particularly when they are well-informed about the benefits and credibility of the product's sustainability claims. For example, a Nielsen survey found that globally, 73% of consumers were willing to pay more for sustainable products.

Governments have also encouraged sustainable consumption practices with a range of incentives such as carbon tax, eco-labeling, sustainable certifications, and other programs to motivate greener behaviors of the consumers. These eco-friendly initiatives likely support and inform consumers' willingness to pay a premium for sustainable products.

However, it is worth noting that price remains an essential factor in the purchasing decision for many consumers, particularly in challenging economic times. Thus, ensuring that sustainable products are affordable and have competitive pricing compared to non-sustainable products can prove critical in driving consuption changes towards more sustainable options.

Overall, while consumers may still be cost-driven, the increasing trend in sustainability awareness and government-supported green initiatives can lead to more willingness among consumers to pay a premium for sustainable and responsible products.
